subject: Re: [junit] Re: Testing Private Methods

messageBody:
Cédric Beust ♔ wrote:

>On 2/12/07, Robert Martin <UncleBob@...> wrote:
>
>
>> I don't feel bad about making private methods package scope in order
>> to test them. Testing trumps encapsulation
>>
>>
>
>Agreed.
>
>
>
>> However, if I can cover (as measured with a coverage tool) the
>> private methods by calling public methods, I will do that rather than
>> test the private methods explicitly.
>>
>>
>
>Doesn't this implicitly imply that unit testing is optional, since you can
>achieve the same goal with functional tests?
>
>Functional tests are here for the user's comfort, unit tests are here for
>the programmer's comfort. Sure, my coverage can tell me that a certain part
>of my application is tested indirectly, but if I don't have unit tests for
>them, locating the bug will be harder for me since there will be multiple
>suspects for the location of the bug.
>
>Consider the following example: I have to display a sorted list in a web
>page, and I only have a functional test that verifies that the HTML is
>correct. My coverage confirms that my ordering logic is run during the
>tests. In this situation, the ordering logic is private and not directly
>tested.
>
>A user reports that the list is not sorted correctly, and now I find myself
>with at least two possible locations to investigate: the HTML generation
>and the sorting logic.
>
>If I had written a test for the private sorting logic, I would know right
>away where the bug is.
>
>
True enough, but there's no particular reason why the logic has to be
private. I'd be leery of a class that generates HTML and sorts. If the
sort is an another class, it can be public and far easier to test.

Michael Feathers
